questions.text: Each muscle spindle consists of ______ intrafusal fibers.
questions.solution:
• Each muscle spindle is 3 to 10 millimeters long. It is built around 3 to 12 tiny intrafusal muscle fibers that are attached to the glycocalyx of the surrounding large extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers.
  • Each intrafusal muscle fiber is a tiny skeletal muscle fiber. However, the central region of each of these fibers has few or no actin and myosin filaments. Therefore, this central portion does not contract when the ends do. Instead, it functions as a sensory receptor. The end portions that do contract are excited by small gamma motor nerve fibers.

questions.text: Motor supply to muscle spindle is _______
questions.solution:
Motor supply to muscle spindle is γ

Muscle spindles have a motor nerve supply of their own.These nerves belong to Erlanger and Gasser’s Aɣ group. They are just 3–6 μ in diameter (hence called small motor nerve system/ɣ efferents of Leksell) and go exclusively to muscle spindles. 

Note:

  • Motor innervation of muscle spindle is by gamma efferents 
  • Motor innervation of extrafusal fibers is by alpha motor neurons

Nuclear bag muscle fibers: 1–3 per muscle spindle.

Nuclear chain muscle fibers: 3–9 per muscle spindle.

questions.text: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the fiber in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron.  

Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle “tone.” 

Option (b):

The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the motor unit.

Option (c):

A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure.

Option (d):

A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following is false with respect to muscle spindles?

choices.text: The intrafusal and extrafusal fibers are positioned paralled to each other
The primary endings of intrafusal fibers are most sensitive to a dynamic response
Type II nerve fibers do not innervate static nuclear bag fibers
Two types of γ motor neurons supply the muscle spindle

questions.solution:
Type II nerve fibers do innervate the static nuclear bag fibers. They do not innervate dynamic nuclear bag fibers.

A muscle spindle has:

  • Intrafusal fibers - these are tiny skeletal muscles which have few or no actin and myosin filaments in the central portion. This portion acts as a sensory receptor.
  • Extrafusal fibers

These fibers are positioned parallel to each other (Option A).

There are two types of intrafusal fibers:

  • Nuclear bag fibers - subdivided as dynamic and static nuclear bag fibers
  • Nuclear chain fibers

Sensory nerve supply: There are two types of sensory endings:

  • Primary endings - (annulospiral ending) from Type Ia nerve fibers. This innervates both the nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. They are most sensitive to the velocity of the change in muscle length. This is called a dynamic response. (Option B)
  • Secondary endings - from Type II nerve fibers. This innervates static nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. They do not innervate dynamic nuclear bag fibers. (Option C) 

Both primary and secondary endings show a static response.

Motor nerve supply: The muscle spindles are supplied by γ motor neurons. There are two types of γ motor neurons- dynamic that supply dynamic nuclear bag fibers and static that supply static nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers. (Option D)

This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy.

questions.text: Which of the following is sensed by the nuclear bag fibers?
questions.solution:
The nuclear bag fibers sense the dynamic length of the muscle.

Nuclear bag fibers are intrafusal fibers, which are a part of the muscle spindle. Intrafusal fibers serve a purely sensory function in the muscle spindle.

questions.text: The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate  _____
questions.solution:
The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate both - nuclear bag and chain fibers.

The afferents for the DTRs are the type Ia and type II nerve fibers. There are three types of intrafusal muscle fibers: dynamic nuclear bag, static nuclear bag, and nuclear chain fibers. A single Ia afferent fiber innervates all three types of fibers to form a primary sensory ending. A group II sensory fiber innervates nuclear chain and static bag fibers to form a secondary sensory ending.

Deep tendon reflexes are an example of stretch reflex or myotatic reflex.

questions.text: Stimulus for stretch reflex is_____
questions.solution:
Stretch reflex occurs when the muscle is stretched passively.

Stretch (myotatic) reflex is monosynaptic. (As illustrated in the figure given below, steps 1→5).

questions.text: Withdrawal reflexes are not____

choices.text: Prolonged if the stimulus is strong
An example of a flexor reflex
Accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body

questions.solution:
Withdrawal reflexes are not accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body. On the ipsilateral side of the pain stimulus, flexors are stimulated (they contract) and extensors are inhibited (they relax), and the arm is jerked away from the stove. On the contralateral side, flexors are inhibited and extensors are stimulated (crossed extension reflex) to maintain balance.

It results in flexion on the ipsilateral side and extension on the contralateral side.

Somatosensory and pain afferent fibers elicit withdrawal of the stimulated body part from the noxious stimulus.

Pain (e.g., touching a hot stove) stimulates the flexor reflex afferents of groups II, III, and IV.

The afferent fibers synapse polysynaptically (via interneurons) onto motoneurons in the spinal cord.

As a result of persistent neural activity in the polysynaptic circuits, an afterdischarge occurs. The afterdischarge prevents the muscle from relaxing for some time.

questions.text: The maintenance of normal posture depends on_____
questions.solution:
The maintenance of normal posture depends on the Integrity of reflex arc.

The muscles that maintain upright posture—that is, support the body’s weight against gravity—are controlled by the brain and by reflex mechanisms.

Three levels of the nervous system control movement:

  • The spinal cord, which integrates spinal reflexes and contains central pattern generators.
  • The brain stem and cerebellum, which control postural reflexes and hand and eye movements.
  • The cerebral cortex and basal ganglia, which are responsible for voluntary movements.

questions.text: Receptor for inverse stretch reflex_____
questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ is the receptor for inverse stretch reflex (refer figure).

The Golgi tendon organs, unlike the spindles, are in series with the muscle fibers; therefore, they are stimulated by both passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle.

The degree of stimulation by contraction of muscles is much greater than that caused by the stretching of muscles.

Muscle contraction → Ib fibers from the Golgi tendon organ excite an inhibitory interneuron that releases inhibitory mediator glycine → hyperpolarization (inhibition) of α motor neurons → muscle relaxation.

questions.text: The number of muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ is ___.
questions.solution:
There are 3-20 muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ.

  • Golgi tendon organ consists of a netlike collection of knobby nerve endings among the fascicles of a tendon.
  • There are 3–25 muscle fibers per Golgi ten­don organ.
  • The fibers from the Golgi tendon organs make up the Ib group of myelinated, rapidly conducting sensory nerve fibers.
  • Golgi tendon organs help in regulating the velocity of the muscle contraction, muscle length, and muscle force.
  • They are the receptor for inverse stretch reflex.

questions.text: The inverse stretch reflex_____

choices.text: Occurs when Ia spindle afferents are inhibited
Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the Golgi tendon organ
Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs
Is a polysynaptic reflex with many interneurons inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs

questions.solution:
Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite, or inverse, of the stretch reflex.

When tension on the muscle—and therefore on the tendon—becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the golgi tendon organ can be so great that it leads instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction; it is probably a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

questions.text: All of the following are true about withdrawal reflex except ______

choices.text: Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal are present
Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits are present
Circuits to cause afterdischarge that lasts many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over are present
The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex pass directly to the anterior motor neurons making it a monosynaptic reflex

questions.solution:
The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex do not pass directly to the anterior motor neurons; instead, they first pass into the spinal cord interneuron pool of neurons and only secondarily to the motor neurons. The shortest possible circuit is a three- or four-neuron pathway. The following basic types of circuits are present:

  • Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal;
  • Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits; and
  • Circuits to cause after-discharge are present. They prolong the reflex contraction of the muscles that last many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over.

The flexor reflex is organized to withdraw a pained or otherwise irritated part of the body from a stimulus. Further, because of after-discharge, the reflex can hold the irritated part away from the stimulus for 0.1 to 3 seconds after the irritation is over. During this time, other reflexes and actions of the central nervous system can move the entire body away from the painful stimulus.

questions.text: Muscle tone is maintained by_____
questions.solution:
The resistance of a muscle to stretch is often referred to as its tone or tonus and muscle spindle helps to control basic muscle tone.

The tonic (static) stretch reflex circuit includes both group Ia and group II afferent fibers from muscle spindles. Normally, there is ongoing activity in the Ia and II afferents that helps maintain a baseline firing of α motor neurons; therefore, the tonic stretch reflex contributes to muscle tone.

questions.text: Which of the following is true during initiation of voluntary movements?

choices.text: Α α motor neurons are activated followed by γ motor neuron
Α γ motor neurons are activated followed by α motor neuron
Both α and ɣ motor neurons are activated together
Only α motor neurons are activated

questions.solution:
The cell bodies of α and γ motor neurons to a given muscle lie close together. Both types are activated by interneurons in their immediate vicinity and sometimes directly by neurons of the descending pathways. During many voluntary and involuntary movements, they are coactivated, i.e., they are excited at almost the same time. (α-ɣ coactivation)

The purpose of α-ɣ coactivation:

  • First, it keeps the length of the receptor portion of the muscle spindle from changing during the course of the whole muscle contraction. Hence, the muscle contraction is not opposed by the stretch reflex.
  • Second, if the muscle spindle did not contract and relax along with the large muscle fibers, the receptor portion of the spindle would sometimes be flail and sometimes be overstretched.

Coactivation thus ensures that information about muscle length will be continuously available to provide for adjustment during ongoing actions and to plan and program future movements.

questions.text: Righting reflex is____
questions.solution:
Righting reflexes operate to maintain the normal standing position and keep an animal's head upright. These reflexes are a series of responses integrated for the most part in the nuclei of the midbrain.

questions.text: In a patient with decerebrate rigidity, on applying pressure on the footpad, extension of that limb occurs. Which of the following statements is false regarding this phenomenon?

choices.text: It is integrated at the Spinal Level
It helps to prevent falling on that side
It is a righting reflex integrated at midbrain level

questions.solution:
Pressure on the footpad of a decerebrate patient causes the limb to extend against the pressure applied to the foot. This reflex is called the positive supportive reaction and is a righting reflex integrated at the spinal level.

Pressure on one side causes extension in that direction (e.g., on applying pressure on the right footpad, extension of the right lower limb occurs), an effect called the magnet reaction. It is seen in infants and following spinal transection.

From an evolutionary perspective, this reflex helps to prevent falling on the side where the stimulus is given.

questions.text: Pyramids are formed by____
questions.solution: The corticospinal pathways are also called the pyramidal tracts or pyramidal system because of their triangular shape as they pass along the ventral surface of the medulla oblongata.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about corticospinal tract?
questions.solution:
The corticospinal tract contains crossed fibers (majority).

Fibers of the corticospinal tract originate from the primary motor cortex (about 30%), the premotor and supplementary motor areas (30%), and the somatosensory areas posterior to the central sulcus (40%).

Most fibers (80% fibers) decussate (cross) in the medullary pyramids and descend in the lateral white matter of the spinal cord to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They control the movements of the contralateral limbs.

The remaining 20% make up the ventral corticospinal tract. These fibers remain uncrossed until reaching the spinal cord where axons terminate bilaterally on spinal interneurons antecedent to motor neurons. These fibers control the movements of the axial musculature.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the origin of corticospinal tract?

choices.text: Corticospinal tract fibers originate from Betz Cells
30% from premotor and supplementary motor areas

questions.solution:
30% of corticospinal tract originates about from the primary motor cortex, not 90%.

30 % from the premotor and supplementary motor areas. 40 % from the somatosensory areas posterior to the central sulcus. 

Betz cells

  • Some large myelinated fibres in the corticospinal tract originate from giant pyramidal cells, also known as Betz cells.
  • Found in the layer 5 of primary motor cortex.
  • These large fibers represent only 3 percent of the total fibers of the corticospinal tract. (The other 97 percent less than 4 micrometers in diameter that conduct background tonic signals to the motor areas of the cord.)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extrapyramidal tract?
questions.solution:
Corticospinal tract is a pyramidal tract . 

Pyramidal tracts (corticospinal and corticobulbar) pass through the medullary pyramids.

All others are extrapyramidal tracts and originate primarily in the the brain stem.

questions.text: Which pathway is not involved in maintainence of posture?
questions.solution:
Rubrospinal tract is not involved in posture maintenance.

Medial motor system

  • Controls the axial muscles (muscles of the trunk)
  • Axial muscles are concerned with postural adjustments and gross movements

Lateral motor system

  • Controls the distal muscles
  • Distal muscles mediate fine, skilled movements

questions.text: Gamma motor neurons are mainly influenced by _____
questions.solution:
• The pontine and medullary reticulospinal tracts are involved in maintainance of posture and in modulating muscle tone especially via an input to ɣ- motor neurons.
  • Pontine reticulospinal neurons are primarily excitatory and medullary reticulospinal neurons are primarily inhibitory.
  • Stimulation of γ-motor neurons does not lead directly to detectable contraction of the muscles because the intrafusal fibers are not strong enough or plentiful enough to cause short­ening.
  • However, stimulation does cause the contractile ends of the intrafusal fibers to shorten and therefore stretches the nuclear bag portion of the spindles, deforming the endings, and initiating impulses in the Ia fibers . This in turn can lead to reflex contraction of the muscle.
  • Thus, muscles can be made to contract via stimulation of the α-motor neu­rons that innervate the extrafusal fibers or the γ-motor neu­rons that initiate contraction indirectly via the stretch reflex.

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except ______

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the ɣ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.solution:
In decerebrate rigidity, there is rigidity in extensor muscles of all the four extremities (not all muscles of the body).

Decerebration

  • Complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculi permits the brain stem pathways to function independently of their input from higher brain structures. This is called a mid-collicular decerebration.
  • This lesion interrupts all input from the cortex (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and red nucleus (rubrospinal tract), primarily to distal muscles of the extremities.
  • The excitatory and inhibitory reticulospinal pathways (primarily to postural extensor muscles) remain intact.
  • The dominance of drive from ascending sensory pathways to the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leads to hyperactivity in extensor muscles in all four extremities which are called decerebrate rigidity.
  • The excitatory input from the reticulospinal pathway activates γ-motor neurons which indirectly activate α-motor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity). This is called the gamma loop.

Option 4. Spinal shock is different from decebrate rigidity as it is a transient state that can occur immediately after a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by a temporary loss or depression of spinal reflexes below the level of the injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity?

choices.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.solution:
• Removal of the cerebral cortex (decortication) produces decorticate rigidity.
  • Characterized by flexion of the upper extremities at the elbow and extensor hyperactivity in the lower extremities.
  • The flexion can be explained by active rubrospi­nal excitation of flexor muscles in the upper extremities; the hyperextension of lower extremities is due to the same changes that occur after midcollicular decerebration.

questions.text: Which of the following reflex is absent in a decorticate animal?
questions.solution:
The Hopping and Placing reflex is absent in a decorticate animal as it is integrated in the cerebral cortex. Rest of the reflexes are integrated below the cortex.

questions.text: Destruction of anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to _________.

choices.text: Increased rigidity via alpha motor neuron

questions.solution:
Destruction of the anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to an increased rigidity via alpha motor neuron.

If the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is removed in a decerebrate animal, extensor muscle hyperactivity is exaggerated (decerebellate rigidity). This cut eliminates cortical inhibition of the cerebellar fastigial nucleus and secondarily increases excitation to vestibular nuclei. Subsequent dorsal root section does not reverse the rigidity, hence proving that the rigidity is due to activation of α-motor neurons independent of the gamma loop.

questions.text: Upper Motor Neurons (UMN) include ______
questions.solution:
• Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons.
  • Corticospinal tract contain a population of large myelinated fibers with a mean diameter of 16 micrometers. These fibers originate from giant pyramidal cells, called Betz cells, that are found only in the primary motor cortex.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man meets with an accident and develops spinal cord transection. Which of the following features will be seen as a result of pyramidal tract injury below the level of motor decussation?
questions.solution:
Cutting the pyramidal tract below the decussation (UMN lesion) causes abnormal plantar extensor reflex (posi­tive Babinski sign).

It initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), and hyperactive stretch reflexes.

The image below shows the pyramidal tract (corticospinal pathway).

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presented to the ER following a road traffic accident. Which of the following features would not be present if there is a corticospinal tract involvement?
questions.solution:
Cog-wheel rigidity is not seen if there is a corticospinal tract involvement. Cogwheel rigidity is seen in extrapyramidal tract involvement when there is a tremor superimposed on hypertonia (e.g., Parkinsonism).

In an upper motor neuron lesion, there is damage to the corticospinal or corticobulbar fibres. If the corticospinal fibres are damaged, it leads to diminished or loss of superficial reflexes, shows an extensor plantar response (Babinski's sign) with loss of fine skilled movement and spasticity.

questions.text: While exercising, a 42-year-old woman developed sudden onset of tingling in her right leg and an inability to control movement in that limb. A neurologic exam showed a hyperactive knee jerk reflex and a positive Babinski sign. Which of the following is not true regarding her condition?

choices.text: Reflexes can be modified by impulses from various parts of the CNS
Reflexes may involve simultaneous contraction of some muscles and relaxation of others
Reflexes are chronically suppressed after spinal cord transection
Reflexes often occur without conscious perception

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal cord transection, which is characterized by an exaggeration of reflexes and not suppression.

Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons. Damage to these neurons, as in transection of the spinal cord, initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), hyperactive reflexes, and abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of medically controlled atrial fibrillation develops sudden onset weakness in the right side of his body. Which of the following Broadman's area is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute stroke, most probably due to atrial fibrillation induced thromboembolism. Since the patient has developed motor weakness in the right side of his body, he most likely has an infarct affecting the primary motor cortex ( broadmann area 4).

  • The primary motor cortex (or just the motor cortex) can be defined as the region of the cortex from which movements are elicited with the least amount of electrical stimulation.
  • It is essentially congruent with Brodmann's cytoarchitectonic area 4.
  • The primary motor cortex (M1) is in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe, extending into the central sulcus.

questions.text: Skilled voluntary movement is initiated by____
questions.solution:
Commands for voluntary movements originate in cortical association areas.

The corticospinal and corticobulbar system (originating in the motor cortex located in precentral gyrus) is the primary pathway for the initiation of skilled voluntary movement.

The movements are planned in the cortex as well as in the basal ganglia and the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres.

The basal ganglia and cerebellum funnel information to the premotor and motor cortex by way of the thalamus.

Motor commands from the motor cortex are relayed in large part via the corticospinal tracts to the spinal cord.

Movement sets up alterations in sensory input from the special senses and from muscles, tendons, joints, and the skin. This feedback information, which adjusts and smooths movement, is relayed directly to the motor cortex and to the spinocerebellum.

questions.text: In the homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation?
questions.solution:
In a homunculus, the more the representation of an area, the more precise the movements are. 

  • The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to the use of the part.
  • The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized sensory receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body.
  • Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex—the lips the greatest of all, followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

questions.text: In the degrees of representation of the different muscle areas as mapped by Penfield and Rasmussen in the primary motor cortex, which of the following has the maximum representation?
questions.solution:
As seen from the figure given below, Vocalization > Salivation > Mastication > Thumb

The topographical organization is demonstrated graphically in the figure, which shows the degrees of representation of the different muscle areas as mapped by Penfield and Rasmussen. This mapping was done by electrically stimulating the different areas of the motor cortex in human beings who were undergoing neurosurgical operations. 

The face is represented bilaterally. The rest of the body has a unilateral representation.

questions.text: While doing a neurosurgical procedure, the paracentral lobules of both hemispheres were damaged. It will lead to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Damage to both paracentral lobules will cause paraplegia.

The paracentral lobule is the medial continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri. It controls motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower extremity. It is also responsible for the control of defecation and urination.

questions.text: Setting posture before planned movement is associated with ____.
questions.solution:
• The premotor cortex may be concerned with a setting posture at the start of a planned movement and getting the individual prepared to move. It is most involved in control of proximal limb muscles needed to orient the body for movement.
  • It is located anterior to the precentral gyrus, on the lateral and medial cortical surface; it also con­tains a somatotopic map almost identical to the topographic organization in primary motor cortex with the mouth and face areas located most laterally. As one moves upward, the hand, arm, trunk, and leg areas are encountered. (as seen in the figure below)
  • This region receives input from sensory regions of the parietal cortex and projects to primary motor cortex (M1), the spinal cord, and the brainstem reticular formation.
  • A special class of neurons called mirror neurons becomes active when a person performs a specific motor task or when he or she observes the same task performed by others. These neurons transform sensory representations of acts that are heard or seen into motor representations of these acts.

questions.text: A  quadriplegic man with a high cervical lesion develops sudden onset of flushing, sweating, pounding headache and hypertension. He has a distended bladder due to a blocked urinary catheter. On immediate drainage of the urinary bladder and repositioning him from supine to reclining, his symptoms resolve. Which of the following is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: SBP may rise over 200 mm Hg
Major portion of the body’s skeletal muscle go into extensor spasm
Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal mass reflex which is seen in patients with a high spinal lesion. A major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasm, and not extensor spasm, in a spinal mass reflex.

Mass Reflex: In a spinal animal or human being, sometimes the spinal cord suddenly becomes excessively active, causing massive discharge in large portions of the cord. The usual stimulus that causes this excess activity is a strong pain stimulus to the skin or excessive filling of a viscus, such as over-distention of the bladder or the gut. The mass reflex involves large portions or even all of the cord.

The effects are as follows: 

  1. A major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasms;
  2. The colon and bladder are likely to evacuate;
  3. The arterial pressure often rises to maximal values, sometimes to a systolic pressure well over 200 mm Hg; and
  4. Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating.

The mechanism is similar to the mechanism of epileptic seizures, which involve reverberating circuits that occur in the brain instead of in the cord.
